children.subject: (Also I don't think there exists a D-, there's only C-, followed by a D, followed by an F)

Thanks for your reply. The EE16B syllabus' point range for D grades is narrow, which might help explain your post. The difference between C and D grades are a few points out of the 25 question final, and although I hope my score does not go anywhere near those thresholds I am thinking the added peace of mind might be helpful given the consequences.

For what it's worth, looking at the past few semesters' grading distributions on BerkeleyTime, almost zero Ds are given. It's either C-es or Fs, and I think there might be other reasons beyond performing poorly on the final that led to an F (cheating, not doing a single lab, not showing up to an exam at all etc.) . I think almost everyone will get a C- or above, so I don't know if taking it for a grade will help.

history.content: I remember reading somewhere that it's a D-, but I can't find a source for it. D-, hopefully this help https://registrar.berkeley.edu/faculty-staff/grading/grading-policies-reports
I remember reading somewhere that it's a D-, but I can't find a source for it. D-, hopefully this helps http://guide.berkeley.edu/academic-policies/academic-policies.pdf
<md>I remember reading somewhere that it's a D-, but I can't find a source for it.</md>

children.subject: D- if letter grade, C- if pnp.

history.content:
Hello, does anyone know the lowest letter grade for a technical course that will fulfill requirements to graduate? Is it D-?

I am an EECS major expecting to graduate this semester (Spring 2020) and am considering switching EE16B to a letter grade since, as I understand, to graduate with pass/no pass I need at least C- whereas if graded I need D-.

Wish I were not asking this question, but am concerned about the multiple choice final that is worth more than half my grade.

Edit: An adviser confirmed in an appointment that it is D–.
history.subject: Lowest major requirement course grade to graduate
